cab.content: This Document ifColonel W. Dally Jones. . . juup Property of209imentHI 5iSECRET.MINISTET OPFOOD.Iteport forWeek ending Wednesday, January 15, 1919.PART h-ACTION TAKEN. The Right Hon. G. H. Roberts, M.P., lias succeeded the Right Hon. J. R. clynes,M.P., as Food Controller. In a statement issued to tho Press on the subject of this country's part in therevictualment of Europe, the new Food Controller pointed out that the continuance ofcontrol here was governed by the needs of Europe as a whole. Victory had its obligations and we were not going to shirk them. Great tracts of the Continent were on the verge of starvation and the problem could only be grappled with by inter-allied action. The Supreme Inter-Allied Council of Supply and Relief had been setup to meet the situation and he was going at once to Paris to confer with the british representatives. The third meeting of the Supreme Council of Supply and Relief was held onMonday, the 13th inst., at the Ministry of Commerce, Paris. A statement was beforethe Council summarising the present position of relief work in regard to Belgium,Northern France, South Eastern Europe, and Northern Europe. Resolutions were passed as to the appointment of committees representative of the four associated governments to supervise arrangements in certain districts. Generally speaking, the position in regard to Allied and liberated territories isthat there is a sufficient world supply of food available to meet their needs. Pendingthe presentation of the detailed report by the representatives of the four Treasuries,it was agreed in principle that all four countries should participate in the financial arrangements. Consideration was given to the position of the neutrals in the matter of food supplies and of Bulgaria, and an agreement was also reached on certain questions ofthe Coimcil's organisation. The Food Council. Meetings of the Council were held on Thursday, January 9th,and Tuesday, January 14th. It was decided that proposals by the Wheat Commission to alter prices should bereferred to the Food Council before announcement, and that the Food Council shouldbe consulted before any food supply was removed from the schedule. The Council considered a memorandum by the Imports Board, setting forth theeffect here of the abolition (by the United States) of restrictions on export in the caseof various articles of food, in particular frozen and canned meat and hog products.With regard to frozen meat the Council took the view that control of refrigeratedtonnage would ensure sufficient control over supplies ; with regard to canned meat itwas agreed that relaxation of control would be desirable and that steps should betaken to dispose of stocks held ; with regard to bacon and hams it was agreed that prices should be maintained for the present. The Council have decided that the restrictions on the purchase of cooking fats bycaterers should be withdrawn as from February 2nd, but that in the case of lardcaterers should, like individual customers, be required to purchase from supplierswith whom they are registered. The Council acceded to a request of the United States Naval Authorities to takeover stores of foodstuffs in this country not now required by them. It was agreed that, in view of the serious shortage of butter anticipated later inthe year, the Treasury should be pressed to sanction the purchase of .11,000 tons fromthe Argentine. A memorandum on the de-scheduling of rye, Rangoon beans and other cerealswas submitted by the Wheat Commission. It was agreed that the Food council should recommend the Food Controller to de-schedule and de-control rye and Rangoonbeans. A preliminary discussion, took place as regards rice, and it was agreed thatINTER-ALLIED FOOD CONTROL.A (83)7191-2 Pk9 145 1/19 B&SA before any decision could be arrived at it was necessary to ascertain the policy of theGovernment with respect to maintaining the prices of home cereals. The Imports Board. The Board have agreed that, subject to a report from theCondensed Milk Section of the Ministry, there will be no need to place any buyingorder for any commodity for February in the United States. With regard to the purchases of butter in the United States the Board report thatthe position is as follows : The United States Food Administration have requisitioned,on behalf of the British Government, 8,000 tons of butter. Of this quantity, contracts have been placed for 7,000 tons, and of these 7,000 tons 4,500 tons have been shipped.There are, therefore, 2,500 tons of butter on which contracts have been placed, whichhas not been shipped, and 1,000 tons for which contracts remain to be placed. Ifthis quantity of butter is not obtained from the United States, the 1 oz. ration willnot be affected and it would not necessarily defer the 2 oz. ration; it would, however,mean a reversion to the 1 oz. ration at an earlier date than is at present anticipated.This represents the position in respect of the present season. It is hoped 5,000 tonsof next season's output (June-October) could be obtained but this only representsabout 5 per cent, of the expected supplies during 1919. Owing to the large stocks of lard in this country, a cable has been sent limiting the shipments from the United States to 2,500 tons a week. Negotiations are proceeding for the purchase of 16,000 tons of tallow and premierjus from Australia. Further steps are being taken to get imporfrestrictions on tallowand stearine removed. With regard to the export of American bacon from this country the Board havecabled to the Allied Provisions Export Commission to the effect, that no bacon hadbeen yet exported but that negotiations are proceeding for the export of 12,000 tons to Holland, 2,500 tons to Norway, and 1,500 tons to Serbia, a total of 16,000 tons.That the question of replacement and the whole general position is being discussed by Sir John Beale with Mr. Hoover in Paris, and that meanwhile no orders are to beplaced until the receipt of further instructions. The present bacon situation is, briefly, as follows : (i) The Bacon Board have already stocks of American and Canadian bacon on hand to last for 15, and possibly 17, weeks; (ii) The Army authorities have notified the Bacon Board that the Army will require no more supplies at present; (iii) If the proposed export negotiations are not arranged, the Bacon Board will only be able to handle 10,000, instead of 12,000 tons a week ; (iv) A letter has been received from the Swedish Government Trade Office asking : if approval may be given to an importation into Sweden of 10,000 tons of hog products from the United Kingdom. A cable has been sent by the Board to the Allied Provisions Export Commissionto the effect that the Treasury have cancelled all credits granted prior to November 1stby the United States' authorities, if such credits have not yet been acted upon. It was agreed to cable to Norway requesting the Norwegian authorities toauthorise the representative they are sending to England, regarding the purchaseof Argentine meat, horseflesh, and hog products, to deal with the negotiations for thesale of potatoes. It has been agreed that half of the crop of Tasraanian apples, amounting to17,000 tons, should be brought along in refrigerated space on private account. The Central Agricultural Advisory Council. The thirteenth meeting was held onthe 7th January ; the following resolution was carried by the Council: That the Presidents of the Departments of Agriculture be urged to appoint a Commission.of Inquiry in co-operation with the Board of Trade and Ministry of Food into the activities of the American Meat Trust, with special reference to the injury likely to be inflicted by such activities upon both the United Kingdom and the British Empire pastoral interests, and that this Commission should consider also what developments or trade organisations are best fitted to safeguard and promote home production. Further resolutions asked : (1) That the control of feeding stuffs should be removed at the earliest possible moment. (2) That a definite intimation should be given either guaranteeing a reasonable price for the 1919 crop'of potatoes or stating that no special effort to produce is required. (3) That the Ministry should take immediate action to secure the release of the men now urgently needed for the cultivation of the 1919 harvest. (4) That the position with regard to the distribution of basic slag and potash should be investigated, a fair proportion of high-grade material being allotted to the British farmer. The Agricultural Costings Committee has been set up jointly by the Board ofAgriculture and Fisheries for England and Wales, the Board of Agriculture forScotland, the Department of Agriculture and Technical Instruction for Ireland, andthe Ministry of Food. It is desired that the Committee should stand in an. advisory capacity in reference to the arrangements made by the Government Departmentsconcerned, or carried on under their supervision, for acquiring and utilising informationas to the costs of farming and the financial results therefrom, and that it should seton foot schemes for extending and elaborating- the scant information at present available. For this purpose it is intended that the Committee should utilise to thefullest extent the Institute for Research in Agricultnral Economics at Oxford, which already possesses a considerable amount of detailed information. The Consumers Council. The Council met on Tuesday, January 14th. Thequestion of de-rationing jam was further considered. A report was received of theconference between representatives of the Ministry, the Consumers' Council and theTrade. The position is that the Consumers' Council will not advise the FoodController to take jam and marmalade oil the coupon till they can be absolutelyassured that the very small supplies of jam (estimated, at two weeks' ration) will beequitably distributed. LABOUR CONFERENCE, The eighth London Labour Conference was held at Grosvenor House on the 11thinst., at which 200 delegates were present from the London Trades Councils, LabourParties and Co-operative Societies. A resolution was carried unanimously, urging the Government to extend the scopeof these conferences to embrace the work of other Government Departments, so thatall conditions and requirements of the workers' lives should receive consideration.Apart from several technical questions raised, the conference adopted a resolutionasking the Government to take over the nation's food resources, all land, and all means of transport. SUPPLIES AND DISTRIBUTION. Bacon, Hams, and l^ard. Arrangements have been reached between Englishwholesalers and Irish wholesalers by means of which the accumulated stocks of american short clear backs and. American cut bellies in the hands of English whole-wholesalers will be sold to Ireland for consumption in that country. It is anticipated thatthis will relieve the trade of a large part of these cuts and that the dissatisfactionwhich was felt at the difficulty of finding a market for them in this country will cease. The demand for lard for the past two weeks through importers does not amountto the 2 oz. ration originally enforced. ' Dried Fruits. Two steamers are reported to have completed loading dates atBasra. One will sail direct to London and the other will call at Bombay. Feeding-stuffs. Instructions have now been issued with regard to the distributionof cattle cake and meals during the remainder of the winter season. Certificates arebeing issued to farmers who apply, enabling them to obtain minimum supplies of cakeor meals for cows in milk, breeding bulls, young calves and ewes in lamb. Suppliesnot required to meet the certificates may be sold without restriction, but a preferencemust be given to farmers wishing to-supplement the minimum allowances for cows inmilk. Concentrated cattle feeding-stuffs other than oil cakes and meals are being released from direct control, but arrangements will be made to assist owners of theabove classes of stock and of pigs who are unable to purchase millers' offals. ' The new arrangements do not entail a great deal of administrative work, and live Stock Commissioners are reducing their clerical, staffs, and giving up accomo-dation that is no longer necessary. It is anticipated that before the end of February the staffs engaged on the controlof feeding-stuffs distribution will be reduced to a minimum. Meat. The arrangements referred to in last week's Report, under which whole areas were to be supplied for given periods with nothing but imported meat, have now been put into operation, and have met with an appreciable measure of success ; the prejudice against the use of frozen meat has disappeared, except in those remoter country districts which are unfamiliar with its value. The stores remain full of imported meat in spite of the larger quantities which have been put into consumption. There is a strong likelihood that, with the reduction in the continental military demands in the near future, it will be necessary to make a further increase in the ration in this country in order to absorb the supplies that will become available. Milk. The supply of milk appears now to be on the up grade, and should continue to increase unless the winter .proves exceptionally hard between now and the early spring. The weekly reports from Divisional Commissioners for the week ending 11th January fully bear out this conclusion. The situation in Greater London gives special cause for satisfaction. As mentioned in the Report for the week ending November 27th, a Committee of the Wholesale Trade has been set up under the Chairmanship of the Home Counties Commissioner, to which is entrusted the distribution of all milk reaching wholesalers who supply Greater London. Week by week the Committee have brought retailers' supplies up or down to a proportion of 85 per cent, of their supplies in the week ending 12th October. This has been done partly by cutting down the supplies of retailers above that level and partly by diverting liquid milk from the manufacturers of milk products in particular, Messrs Nestle. Owing to the increase of production it has been decided to raise the supplies to wholesalers this week to 90 per cent, of their supplies for the week ending October 12th, and, provided this can be done without diverting still more milk from manufacturers, to raise them in the following week to 95 per cent. It is thought best to proceed in this gradual manner, as consumers have now grown accustomed to drink only the 85 per cent, supply, and it is important that when the flush begins they should be ready to increase their consumption. It cannot, therefore, be said that there is any serious shortage in Greater London, though it must be remembered that normally in January consumption in Greater London would be 10 per cent, above the consumption in the middle of October, and not 5 per cent, below. The new pattern 10-gallon churn has been tested for spillage, in the presence of members of the Central Milk Advisory Committee. The test Avas a severe one; the specimens were hand-made, as the tools are not yet ready to make the churn by machinery, which alone would insure precision. The members of the Committee expressed themselves satisfied with the pattern of the churn, and a large number of orders have already been received from the trade. ORDERS UNDER DEFENCE or THE REALM REGULATIONS. An Order amending the Apple Prices Order 1918, dated 1.5th January 1919, permits apples to be sold by weight, where under the old Order they could be sold only by package. The retail price is not altered. An Order, dated lbth January 1919, revolves the Fruit Sales Order, 1918. The"result is to abolish the maximum prices for summer fruits, and to allow the importation into the country of fruit pulp. ENFORCEMENT OF ORDERS. The total number of prosecutions" for the week ending 4th of January is 931, of which 838 resulted in convictions. The prosecutions were reported under 69 Orders, the greatest number being under the Rationing Order 1918, the Flour and Bread (Prices) Order 1917, and the Grain Order. The large number of cases recorded against retailers who have exceeded controlled prices, points to the fact that profiteering is still very prevalent. The following is a glaring example : A firm of wholesale grocers at Hanworth were recently charged under the Bacon, Ham and Lard, and Canned Meat (Prices) Orders. The defendants, who had over- charged on four occasions for hams, and on two occassions for canned meat, were ordered to pay fines amounting to 1201. and 10L 10s. costs. PART II, SUMMARY OF THE FOOD POSITION. IMPORTS. The net imports of the principal foods and feeding stuffs in the week ended11th January (178,700 tons) were slightly less than the average of the year 1918 and considerably less than the imports in the week ended 4th January which wereabnormal (Table A). There were again good imports of wheat and flour (101,600 tons as equivalentgrain) and improved imports of oats (12,100 tons) and maize (7,100 tons); meat(12,600 tons) and bacon (15,000 tons) imports were also good. On the other handlard imports (600 tons) were again low, and very small quantities of butter (60 tons),cheese (50 tons), rice (500 tons), tea (800 tons), and coffee (80 tons) were entered. The total imports for the lirst 19 weeks of the cereal years 1917-18 and 1918-19are compared in the following table ;--Total Imports for first 19 weeks of Cereal Year.* 1918. Sugar -Tea -Coffee-Cocoa- Ions. 192,900 45,900 16,400 37,000 52,300 393,800 77,200 4,600 36,400 Tons. 4- 103,800 4- 42,000 4- 3,300 - 18,500 - 14,100 4 15,600 - 123,300 4 32,500 4 2,600 4 29,500 4 116 4 1,074 4 25 - 100 - 27 4 43 - 24 4 73 4 131 4 430 2,018,900 + 868,400 + 75 35,000 423,300 225,500 - 150,700 - 204,500 4 7,600 - 81 - 33 4 3 CONSUMPTION. Bread and Flour. The bakers' returns for the four weeks ended January 4th show a.further fall of 1*9 per cent, in the quantity of flour used for bread and sold retail. This cannot be taken, however, as indicating a further fall in the level of consumption, for the decrease is less than half the drop in the preceding two years associated with the seasonable change of fare, and leaves the level of consumption still above that of a year ago. If the exceptionally low figures for Christmas week be omitted, deliveries' of flour from mills show a tendency to increase, but further quantities will be required to replace stocks held by bakers who had allowed them to become depleted in anticipation of further improvements in the quality of the flour. The cancellation of army contracts is entirely responsible for the decrease of 22 per cent, in the total output of biscuit manufacturers, the decrease on this particular class amounting to 66 per cent., compared with the four weeks ended December 7th, and to 83 per cent, on the four weeks ended November 9th. Meat. With the opening of the new year, supplies of home-fed butchers' meat in Great Britain have fallen off sharply, the estimated supply for the week ended 4th January being 11,600 tons. Issues of imported meat were 9,800 tons, making a total supply of 21,400 tons. After deductions, however, for meats not coming within the ration, and for waste, estimated consumption- on the ration was slightly below the higher ration quantity of 18,100 tons. Home supplies were only 54 per cent, of the total, the lowest proportion which has been recorded since June. It is likely to fall still lower in the next few months. Milk. The index number for milk traffic by railway, which is higher for December 1918 than for December 1917 (Table C, 4), reflects the increase in traffic caused by the diversion of milk from districts where there was a relatively plentiful supply, and from factories, to districts where there was acute shortage, The quantity so diverted to London in December was 163,000 gallons. Fish. The supplies of fish at Billingsgate and-the other chief inland markets during the week ended 4th January were 2,400 tons. This was a considerable"improvement on the supplies (1,600 tons) received during the Christmas week, but was only one-third of the average supplies during the first three weeks of December. The nett amount received at Billingsgate market was almost exactly the same as the A 7191-2 B Article. Stocks at end of 1918. Increase or Decrease in Stocks on December 31st compared with September 1st. The returns of retail prices collected by the Department of Labour Statistics as on1st January show an increase of 1 per cent, in the price of milk, which now averages8fd. a quart, and an increase of 5 per cent, in potatoes, now l\d. per 7 lbs. Theweighted average shows an increase in prices of '4 per cent, since December, and129*6 per cent, since July 1914. The general course of prices since the outbreak of war has been a three years'period of rising prices averaging 3 per cent, per month until July 1917, by which date the increase had amounted to 104 per cent., a years pause, during which theincrease averaged \ per cent, per month, and again a period of rising prices from july 1918 (110 per cent, increase.) to November (133 per cent, increase) the figures forDecember and January being 129*0 per cent, and 129'6 per cent, respectively.amount received in the week ending 5th January 1918, and was respectively 7 percent, and 18 per cent, higher than the supply in the corresponding week of 1917and of 1916. STOCKS. The stocks of the principal foods and feeding-stuffs at the end of the year1918 are given in Table D and compared with the stocks a year ago. It will beseen that a very substantial increase is shown in nearly all the commodities enume-rated. Wheat is higher by 858,000 tons, or 40 per cent, barley and maize are less,but oats, barley and maize together are higher by ^8 7,000 tons, or 10 per cent. Sugar-stocks are higher by 128,000 tons, or 60 per cent. Stocks of meat and provisions arealso higher ; meat by 49,000 tons, or 57 per cent., bacon by 37,100 tons, or 400 percent., lard by 29,800 tons, or 828 per cent. Coffee and cocoa stocks in bond havefallen 44 per cent., but tea stocks have been trebled and now amount to 64,600 tonsthe highest level reached since February 1916. The marked improvement in the food position at the end of 1918 may be shown by comparing the depletion or accumulation of stocks of various foodstuffs during thefirst four months of the cereal years. In 1917 the stocks of wheat fell, between the1st September and the 31st December, 35 "7 per cent.; in other words, the stocks ofwheat which had, at the beginning of the cereal year amounted to about 28 weeks'consumption, were (owing mainly to the falling off in imports) so seriously depletedthat on the 31st December they amounted to only 18 weeks' consumption. In thecorresponding period of 1918 the depletion amounted to only 5 per cent. The position of other foods also gave rise to anxiety a year ago, notably bacon,lard, and butter, while stocks of tea were very low. The changed position may beseen from the figures in the following table which gives the stocks at the end of 1918and the percentage change since the 1st September as compared with the change inthe corresponding four months of the two preceding years ; figures are added to show the change in the volume of imports. It will be seen that the low level of stocks of barley and maize, referred to above, is associated with a cumulative decline in imports in the autumn of 1917 and 19.18. January 4th - 85 88$B 3 TABLE D.-STOCKS of the PRINCIPAL FOODS and FEEDING STUFFS, in the UNITED KINGDOM. The figures for wheat and flour include stocks in port granaries and warehouses, inland warehouses,mills, and bakers' shops, as well as estimated stocks on farms ; those for barley, oats, beans, and peasinclude stocks in port granaries and warehouses and in mills, in maltsters' hands, and estimated farm stocks ;those for maize, rice, and grain meals include stocks in port granaries and warehouses and in mills. The figures for sugar are stocks in possession of tho Sugar Commission ; those for butter, margarine,laid, cheese, condensed milk, meat, and fish include stocks at ports, in cold stores, and in importers' andwholesalers' warehouses. The figures for tea, coffee, and cocoa are stocks remaining in bonded warehouses or entered to bewarehoused; and those for oilseeds and oilseed'cake include stocks at ports and in the hands of millers,crushers, and cake manufacturers.Article.January 1st, 191!).December 1st, 1918.January 1st, 191Slocks in the United Kingdom including estimated Farm Stocks.Wheat (including flour)BarleyOatsBeans - . -PeasMaize -Rice (including ground rice and rice flour)Grain Meals -Sugar - - - - -Butter - - - -Margarine ...Lard -Cheese - - - -Condensed milk meat: Beef (chilled and frozen) Mutton (chilled and frozen) Bacon and Hams Poultry, Game, and Rabbits Other MeatFishleaCofleeCocoa Tons.2,975,000 729.0002,426.000 187,000 92,000 Tons.3,088,000 896,0002.953,000 193,000 96,000 Ions.2,117,000 760,0002,087,000 114,000 48,000Stocks in the United Kingdom at Ports, Warehouses, fcc. 25,000 152,000- 53,000 337,000 37,000152,000 50,000381,000 46,000125,000 43.000209,000Stocks in the United Kingdom in Cold Stores and in Importers' and Wholesalers' Warehouses. 8,200 1,70033,40021,80033,60077,60019,10046,400 3,30040,400[-27,000 8,500 1,50033,60026,60043,00072,20019,30059,500 4,70041,20024,800 1,200 2.600 3,600 17,100* 11,900 45,600 22,800 9,300 5,500 19,100 20,700Stocks in the United Kingdom, remaining in Bonded Warehouses, or entered to be Warehoused.64,60030,60025,50061,60035,30019,80016.60055,60045,500Oilseeds, &c.Oilseed Cake and MealStocks in the United Kingdom at Ports and in the hands of Millers, Crushers, and Cake Manufacturers, * In manufacturers' hands only.NUMBER OF LIVE STOCK IN GREAT BRITAIN.
